required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of ReWin(d) Supplementation on the Recovery of DOMS Induced by Acute Exercice
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Dietary Supplementation With ReWin(d) on the Recovery of Young Athletes Suffering From Delayed-Onset Muscle Soreness Induced by Acute Exercice: A Pilot Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The study will assess the recovery and performance of young athletes suffering from muscle damage induced by physical exercise. Model by comparing the safety and efficacy of ReWin(d) supplemention during 4 weeks to placebo over 72 hours post exercice.

detailed_description.textblock:
Double-blind, randomized, placebo controlled, parallel group, pilot safety and efficacy study.
40 healthy young male athetes were randomly assigned to the ReWin(d) or Placebo group. After 4 weeks supplementation (either 2 g daily of ReWin(d) capsules or placebo capsules). the participants were subjected to a 1 hour plyometric exercise session to induce DOMS. At 0 hours, 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours post exercise, the volunteers have been assessed to determine: (i) pain perception, (ii) fatigue rate, (iii) sport performance (effectiveness of a jump) and (iv) muscle damage and inflammation by I-R thermography and biomarkers

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Single dose, Randomized, Double Blinded, Placebo-controlled Study

primary_outcome.measure: Effects of ReWin(d) on muscle recovery induced by physical exercise
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 0 hours, 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours post plyometric exercises session to induce DOMS
primary_outcome.description: Sport performance (effectiveness of a jump) after exercise-induced muscle damage

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of ReWin(d) on muscle damage induced by physical exercise
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 0 hours, 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours post plyometric exercises session to induce DOMS
secondary_outcome.description: Muscle skin temperature monitored by IR-camera.

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of ReWin(d) on pain perception induced by physical exercise
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 0 hours, 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours post plyometric exercises session
secondary_outcome.description: Visual Analogue Scale pain perception after exercise-induced muscle damage

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of ReWin(d) on fatigue rate induced by physical exercise
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 0 hours, 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours post plyometric exercises session
secondary_outcome.description: Heart Rate Variability assessment after exercise-induced muscle damage

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of ReWin(d) on Gut Microbiota
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline dose after 4 weeks of intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Determination of Microbiota composition by 16S rRNA Sequencing.

arm_group.description: Subjects have to take ReWin(d) capsules (3 times a day, total 2 g/day) during breakfast, lunch and diner, during 4 weeks + 3 days after acute exercice
Subjects have to take Placebo capsules (3 times a day, total 2 g/day) during breakfast, lunch and diner, during 4 weeks + 3 days after acute exercice

intervention.description: Supplementation during 4 weeks + 72 hours post acute exercice

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- > 18 years old
- Young athletes
- Training at least 3 times per week
- Agree not to initiate any new exercise or diet programs during the entire study period
- Agree not to change their current diet or exercise program during the entire study period
- Agree not to stretch, utilize ice massage, take anti-inflammatory medications (eg, aspirin, ibuprofen), or use any other treatment for the duration of the trial.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous history of upper extremity injury or knee joint pain
- Use of anti-inflammatory medications or pain medications 1 week before the screening visit and during the study
- Daily use of dietary supplements and herbal supplements beginning at the screening visit and during the study
- Antibiotic use in past 3 months
- Chronic disease

responsible_party.investigator_title: Principal Investigator. Full Profesor in Physical Activity and Sport. Exercise physiology.
